repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - FOVI Restructuring Project,
            Affordable Housing and Urban Poverty Sector Adjustment Loan
            Project, and Second and Third Programmatic Affordable
            Housing and Urban Poverty Development Policy Loan Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Fund for Housing
            Operation and Finance (FOVI) Restructuring Project in Mexico
            were as follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory; risk
            to development outcome was significant; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Affordable Housing and Urban
            Poverty Sector Adjustment Loan Project in Mexico were as
            follows: outcome was unsatisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was significant; Bank performance was unsatisfactory
            and borrower performance was satisfactory. Ratings for the
            Second Affordable Housing and Urban Poverty Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project in Mexico were as follows: outcome
            was unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            significant; Bank performance was unsatisfactory and
            borrower performance was also unsatisfactory. Ratings for
            the Third Affordable Housing and Urban Poverty Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project in Mexico were as follows: outcome
            was moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome
            was significant; Bank performance was unsatisfactory and
            borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Lessons
            learned include: the expected outcomes and scope of an
            operation should be subject to several reality checks at
            appraisal. An important one is to ensure that essential
            partners such as INFONAVIT (National Housing Fund for
            Private Sector Workers) in this case-are fully on board and
            committed to the operation. If they are not, or cannot be
            engaged for reasons of political economy, then an
            operation's scope should be contained to cover the more
            modest outcomes that can reasonably be obtained without such
            partners. In large and sophisticated middle-income countries
            like Mexico, an operation should avoid promising sector-wide
            reforms when commensurate results cannot be realistically
            achieved in the short timeframe and with the relatively
            modest scale of assistance offered. Operations aiming to
            support affordable housing and urban poverty reduction need
            to be explicit about their target beneficiary populations,
            with quantification of baselines and targets, and at
            completion, achievements. Contrary to down-market aims,
            establishing a sound reputation in financial markets and
            sustaining a high quality and expanding portfolio can lead a
            new mortgage financier up-market, by targeting higher income
            borrowers with larger loans. Markets perceive such loans as
            less risky. They are also less costly to manage and
            contribute more to business growth.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Affordable Housing and Urban
            Poverty Sector Adjustment Loan Project, and Second and Third
            Programmatic Affordable Housing and Urban Poverty
            Development Policy Loan Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Affordable Housing and
            Urban Poverty Sector Adjustment Loan Project for Mexico were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, sustainability was likely,
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            institutional development impact was substantial. Ratings
            for the Second and Third Programmatic Affordable Housing and
            Urban Poverty Development Policy Loan Projects for Mexico
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            a policy-based loan is not the best instrument to address
            technical issues requiring considerable investment and which
            are not backed by an adequate policy framework. Instead, a
            combination of policy and investment loans might have been
            more effective in meeting the Program's goals.
            Inefficiencies and redundancies were produced due to the
            involvement of too many institutions, which were often at
            odds with each other over policy issues. This was largely
            due to the large number of components and sectors under the
            umbrella of the Program. A more focused approach, as
            previously mentioned, could have reduced these
            inefficiencies and redundancies. The comprehensive nature of
            the Program required that adequate Monitoring and Evaluation
            (M&E) provisions be written into the design of the
            operation; however this was not done until preparation of
            the second operation was well advanced. Housing and Urban
            Technical Assistance Loan (HUTAL) should have played a role
            in fixing the shortcomings of the Program and its
            implementing institutions in this area. The timing of HUTAL
            should have been better aligned with the Program in order to
            provide added value to each component.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Affordable Housing and Urban
            Poverty Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            substantial. This simplified Implementation Completion
            Report provides some findings and implications for
            subsequent operations as follows. Reforms supported by HUSAL
            have contributed to the recent expansion and diversification
            of market-rate housing credit in the moderate-income
            segment, by leveraging private sector resources, as
            evidenced by an increase in the outstanding mortgage to GDP
            ratio from 4.9 percent in 2000, to 7.3 percent in 2004. To a
            large extent, the elements included in the agreed policy
            matrix will promote this outcome; however special attention
            should be given to the subsidy component. It would be
            advisable to incorporate into the policy matrix the
            development of a comprehensive housing sector database that
            could provide the housing commission with an essential tool,
            necessary to exercise the role as policy body. The
            Program's main objective - improving the living
            conditions of the poor- depends on a broad array of
            variables identified in each of the project's
            components. To different degrees, reform is needed in all of
            them to address the main goal. It is expected these reforms
            will occur gradually, and this is the reason the
            programmatic structure of the project design suits the
            operation. Moreover, there are substantial benefits to be
            gained in favor of sector policy from the Bank's role
            as facilitator between different government agencies,
            fostering policy discussion towards reform. This has been
            recognized by the client as an important, positive impact of
            the Bank's role.

5183186.trustfund:
TF026468-PHRD-MEXICO: FEDERAL DISTRICT
            URBAN DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
5183186.majtheme: Public sector governance,Urban development,Social protection and risk management,Rule of law

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Affordable Housing and Urban
            Poverty Programmatic Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Affordable Housing and Urban Poverty
            Programming Sector Adjustment Loan Project, represents the
            first of a series of quick disbursing loans to support the
            Government of Mexico's low-income housing and urban
            program. To this end, the project goals focus on seven key
            areas: a) develop a sound national policy and institutional
            framework for housing, and urban development; b)design and
            establish a unified housing subsidy policy that facilitates
            access of low/moderate-income families, to housing, and
            leverages household savings, and private credit finance; c)
            strengthen the housing credit, and savings systems; d)
            strengthen urban real property registries, and rights; d)
            increase the supply of urban land and its access by the
            poor, and improve real estate market functions; e)
            coordinate and support physical and social investments, to
            systematically upgrade poor neighborhoods; and, f) improved
            prevention and management of the impacts of natural
            disasters. Risks however, include a relatively ambitious
            cross-sectoral approach, risking the timing approval of the
            second and third loans in the program. However, this risk
            should be mitigated through the well-designed, integrated
            strategy, and a small number of key prior actions, including
            the intended reform policy.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Affordable Housing and Urban
            Poverty Structural Adjustment Loan Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA)
            reviews the institutional framework concerning environmental
            protection policies, and programs related with housing
            construction, to recommend actions to mitigate environmental
            adversity that may result from implementation of the
            Affordable Housing and Urban Poverty Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project in Mexico. From an institutional perspective,
            the report suggests active participation by environmental
            authorities in the housing sector, on policy planning, and
            implementation, supported by a strong legal, and regulatory
            framework. To this end, the conflicts between federal, and
            state programs should be addressed, to then establish
            mechanisms strengthening housing information management
            systems for the provision of housing environmental
            indicators, low-income housing costs, and housing market
            estimates. Housing development should initially consider
            availability of water resources, promote as possible water
            tariffs that reflect real costs, as well as infrastructure
            costs that support water service delivery, and, include an
            adequate water management, and sanitation technology for
            current construction programs, supported by training and
            capacity building. Similarly, power consumption indicators
            should be made available, so that construction plans are in
            accordance with the energy supply. From the urban
            standpoint, roads and urban transportation modes should be
            fostered, taking into account the necessary legal and
            regulatory framework concerning an integrated urban program.

            ambientales en el diseno de programas de vivienda urbana en Mexico
